A report in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', published on November 25, 2018, showed violent right-wing-related incidents up, and left-wing-related incidents down. Total domestic terrorism incidents was down to 41 in 2001, from a high of 468 in 1970, but then went up to 65 in 2017. Of those 65 events in 2017, 36 were right-wing-related (with 11 fatalities), 10 were left-wing-related (with 6 fatalities), 7 were related to Islamist extremism (with 16 fatalities), and 12, including the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]], were categorized as "Other/Unknown" (with 62 fatalities, including 58 from the Las Vegas incident). The report found that 2018 was a particularly deadly year, with 11 people dying in the [[Pittsburgh synagogue shooting]], 2 others in an incident in Kentucky, and two more in a [[2018 Tallahassee shooting|shooting in Tallasshee]]. All three incidents were right-wing related.<ref name=wapo112518>Lowery, Wesley; Kindy, Kimberly; and Ba Tran, Andrew (November 25, 2018) [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/in-the-united-states-right-wing-violence-is-on-the-rise/2018/11/25/61f7f24a-deb4-11e8-85df-7a6b4d25cfbb_story.html "In the United States, right-wing violence is on the rise"] ''[[The Washington Post]]''</ref>
The ''Post'' reported that the upsurge in right-wing violence began during the [[Barack Obama administration]] and picked up steam under the presidency of [[Donald Trump]], whose remarks after the [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlotteville, Virginia]] in 2017 that there were "some very fine people on both sides" is widely seen as giving confidence to the right that the administration looked favorably on their goals, providing them with "tacit support". A former FBI assistant director for counterintelligence, is quoted as saying that "[political leaders] from the White House down, used to serve as a check on conduct and speech that was abhorrent to most people. I see that eroding. ... The current political rhetoric is at least enabling, and certainly not discouraging, violence."<ref name=wapo112518 />
According to analysis by the newspaper of data from the [[Global Terrorism Database]], 92 of 263 domestic terrorism events – 35% – that occurred from 2010 to 2017 were right-wing related, while 38 (14%) were Islamist extremist-related, and 34 (13%) were left-wing related. Not only that, but a criminologist from [[John Jay College]] stated that right-wing attacks were statistically more likely to result in fatalities.<ref name=wapo112518 />
== Europe ==
===Denmark=== Neo-Nazis were suspected to have perpetrated the [[1992 Copenhagen bombing]], in which the office of a left-wing socialist party was attacked, killing one of its members.<ref>https://www.b.dk/nationalt/afdoed-nynazist-haevdes-at-staa-bag-brevbombe?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter</ref>
=== France === In the town of [[Toulon]], a far-right extremist group called SOS-France existed. On 18 August 1986, four members were driving a car carrying explosives, apparently in an attempt to bomb the offices of [[SOS Racisme]]. However it exploded while they were still in it, killing all four of them.<ref>https://www.apnews.com/b94eda4f669fd78ae616120b07cf66e8</ref>
Neo-Nazi members of the [[French and European Nationalist Party]] were responsible for a pair of [[1988 Cannes and Nice attacks|anti-immigrant terror bombings]] in 1988. Sonacotra hostels in [[Cagnes-sur-Mer]] and Cannes were bombed, killing Romanian immigrant George Iordachescu and injuring 16 people, mostly Tunisians. In an attempt to [[False flag|frame Jewish extremists]] for the Cagnes-sur-Mer bombing, the terrorists left leaflets bearing [[Star of David|Stars of David]] and the name [[Masada]] at the scene, with the message "To destroy [[Israel]], Islam has chosen the sword. For this choice, Islam will perish."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Greenhouse|first1=Steven|title=Immigrant Hostel Bombed in France|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/12/20/world/immigrant-hostel-bombed-in-france.html|accessdate=20 October 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=20 December 1988}}</ref>
On 28 May 2008, members of the neo-Nazi Nomad 88 group fired with machine guns at people from their car in [[Saint-Michel-sur-Orge]].<ref>https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2008/06/03/un-groupuscule-neonazi-a-l-origine-d-une-fusillade_1053066_3224.html</ref><ref>http://www.leparisien.fr/essonne/le-groupuscule-neonazi-decide-de-s-autodissoudre-04-06-2008-3298544168.php</ref>
In 2015, in the aftermath of the [[Charlie Hebdo shooting]], six mosques and a restaurant were attacked in acts deemed as right-wing terrorism by authorities.<ref name="Europol16"/> The acts included grenade throwing, shooting, and use of an [[improvised explosive device]].
=== Germany === {{See also|Far-right politics in Germany|Terrorism in Germany}}
In 1980, a [[Oktoberfest terror attack|right-wing terrorist attack in Munich, Germany]] killed the attacker and 12 other people, injuring 215. Fears of an ongoing campaign of major right-wing terrorist attacks did not materialize.{{sfn|Aubrey|2004|p=45}}
In addition to several bank robberies, the German [[National Socialist Underground]] was responsible for the [[Bosphorus serial murders]] (2000–2006), the [[2004 Cologne bombing]] and the murder of policewoman [[Michéle Kiesewetter]] in 2007. In November 2011, two members of the National Socialist Underground committed suicide after a bank robbery and a third member was arrested some days later.
Right-wing extremist offenses in Germany rose sharply in 2015 and 2016.<ref name="Bleiker">Carla Bleiker, [http://www.dw.com/en/sharp-rise-in-right-wing-crime-in-germany-just-the-tip-of-the-iceberg/a-19041652 Sharp rise in right-wing crime in Germany just 'the tip of the iceberg'], [[Deutsche Welle]] (February 11, 2016).</ref> Figures from the German government tallied 316 violent xenophobic offences in 2014 and 612 such offenses in 2015.<ref name="Bleiker"/>
In August 2014, a group of four Germans founded a [[Munich]]-based far-right terrorist group, the {{ill|Oldschool Society|de}}. The group, which held racist, antisemitic, and anti-Muslim views, eventually attracted 30 members.<ref name="APOldschoolsentence">Associated Press, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/15/germany-far-right-terrorist-group-four-jailed Four jailed in Germany for forming far-right terrorist group] (March 15, 2017).</ref> They stockpiled weapons and explosives and plotted to attack a refugee shelter in [[Saxony]],<ref name="APOldschoolsentence"/> but the group's leaders were arrested in May 2015 before carrying out the attack.<ref>Kate Brady, [http://www.dw.com/en/oldschool-society-neo-nazis-go-on-trial-for-refugee-home-attacks/a-19217024 'Oldschool Society' neo-Nazis go on trial for refugee home attacks], [[Deutsche Welle]] (April 27, 2016).</ref> In March 2017 four of the group's leaders were sentenced to prison terms.<ref name="APOldschoolsentence"/> The perpetrator of the [[2016 Munich shooting]] also had far-right views.
=== Italy === In the 1970s and 1980s, Italy endured the [[Years of Lead (Italy)|Years of Lead]], a period characterized by frequent terrorist attacks: between 1969 and 1982, the nation suffered 8,800 terrorist attacks, in which a total of 351 people were killed and 768 were injured.<ref name="Hof">Tobias Hof, "The Success of Italian Anti-terrorism Policy" in ''An International History of Terrorism: Western and Non-Western Experiences'' (editors Jussi M. Hanhimäki & Bernhard Blumenau: Routledge, 2013), p. 100.</ref> The terrorist attacks have been both ascribed to the far-left and the far-right, yet a lot of terrorist attacks remain without a clear culprit and a lot of people have claimed the authorship of them is to be ascribed to rogue members of the Italian secret service. Even some of the terrorist attacks ascribed to a particular political group may be in reality the work of these rogue agents: this has been claimed, among many others, by [[Francesco Cossiga]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2006/11/21/italia/politica/cossiga-le-spie-ve-le-racconto-io-pAUXKv2TCn4Yp824sScL1O/pagina.html |title=Cossiga: «Le spie? Ve le racconto io» - La Stampa |publisher=Lastampa.it |date=2006-11-21 |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref> who was the President of the Italian Republic during the years of lead, and by [[Giulio Andreotti]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Di Stefano Marroni |url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2000/08/03/andreotti-servizi-segreti-si-sentivano-alla-guerra.html |title=Andreotti: I servizi segreti si sentivano alla guerra santa - la Repubblica.it |language={{it icon}} |publisher=Ricerca.repubblica.it |date=2000-08-03 |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref> who, during the same period of time held the Prime Minister office more than once.
The [[Years of Lead]] are considered to have begun with the [[Piazza Fontana bombing]] in [[Milan]] in December 1969,<ref name="Hof"/> perpetrated by [[Ordine Nuovo]], a right-wing [[neofascist]] group.<ref name="McHugh">Richard McHugh, "Ordine Nuovo" in ''The SAGE Encyclopedia of Terrorism'', 2d ed. (editor Gus Martin: SAGE Publications, 2011), pp. 451-52.</ref> Sixteen people were killed, and 90 injured, in the bombing.<ref name="McHugh"/>
In July 1970, this same group carried out a bombing on a train going from Rome to Messina, killing six and wounding almost 100. The group also carried out the [[Piazza della Loggia bombing]] in 1974, killing eight antifascist activists.<ref name="McHugh"/> Perhaps the most infamous right-wing terrorist attack in post-war Italy is the [[August 1980 Bologna bombing]], in which neo-fascist [[Nuclei Armati Rivoluzionari]] ("Armed Revolutionary Nuclei"), an Ordine Nuovo offshoot, killed 85 people and injured 200 at the [[Bologna Centrale railway station|Bologna railroad station]].<ref name="McHugh"/><ref name="1988Convictions">[http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1988/Four-Convicted-Of-Mass-Murder-In-Italian-Bombing-That-Killed-85/id-370c14ae3f77e87d266b0257bf7d2f62 Four Convicted of Mass Murder in Italian Bombing that Killed 85], Associated Press (July 11, 1988).</ref> [[Valerio Fioravanti]], Francesca Mambro, and two others were convicted of mass murder in the attacks,<ref name="1988Convictions"/> although both have always denied any connection with them.<ref>Anna Cento Bull & Philip Cooke, ''Ending Terrorism in Italy'' (Routledge, 2013), pp. 141-42.</ref><ref>Anne Hanley, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/the-accidental-terrorist-1259973.html The accidental terrorist], ''Independent'' (May 5, 1997).</ref>
In December 2011, a gunman targeted Senegalese peddlers in [[Florence]], killing two and injuring three others before killing himself.<ref name="LinksFarRight">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19366000 | publisher=BBC News | title=Viewpoint: Killer Breivik's links with far right | date=August 27, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Kington">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/23/ezra-pound-daughter-italian-fascist | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Tom | last=Kington | title=Ezra Pound's daughter aims to stop Italian fascist group using father's name | date=December 23, 2011}}</ref> The perpetrator was a sympathizer of [[CasaPound]],<ref name="LinksFarRight"/><ref name="Kington"/> which is a neo-fascist party that Italian judges have recognized as not posing a threat to public or private safety.<ref>{{cite web|author=Altri articoli dalla categoria » |url=http://www.repubblica.it/politica/2016/02/01/news/casapound_polizia-132480295/ |title=La polizia "promuove" CasaPound: "La violenza? Colpa dei centri sociali" |publisher=Repubblica.it |date=2016-02-01 |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref>
=== Norway === On July 22, 2011, Norwegian right-wing extremist with Nazi<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2012/04/18/nyheter/terrorsaken/nazismen/breivik/21171974/|title=Close to Nazism|author=Leif Stang|newspaper=Dagbladet|date=18 April 2012|language=Norwegian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://expo.se/2014/breivik-vill-deportera-illojala-judar_6336.html|title=Breivik vill deportera "illojala judar"|newspaper=Expo Idag|language=Swedish|date=10 January 2014|author=Daniel Vergara}}</ref> and fascist<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/22-juli/artikkel.php?artid=10103118|title=Breivik seeks to start the fascist party|date=10 May 2013|newspaper=VG Nett|author=Eva-Therese Grøttum|author2=Marianne Vikås|language=Norwegian}}</ref> sympathies, [[Anders Behring Breivik]], carried out the [[2011 Norway attacks]], the largest mass killing of people in [[Norway]] by a single person during peacetime, excluding use of bombs. First he bombed several government buildings in [[Oslo]], killing eight people and injuring more than 30. After the bombings, he went to [[Utøya]] island in a fake police uniform and began firing on people attending a political youth camp for the [[Workers' Youth League (Norway)|Worker's Youth League]] (AUF), a left-wing political party, killing 68 and injuring more than 60.
===Poland=== {{See also|Far-right politics in Poland}} Despite the country being nearly ethnically and religiously homogenous, Polish far-right targets, via propaganda or physical violence, religious and ethnic minorities such as Jews, [[Romani people]], people with darker complexion or Middle Eastern appearance. In 1991, an [[Mława riot|anti-Romani pogrom broke out in Mława]]. During the [[UEFA Euro 2012]], Polish hooligans targeted random Russian football supporters. There have been reports of hate crimes targeting the [[Islam in Poland|Muslim minority in Poland]]. [[Far-right politics|Far-right]] and [[Right-wing populism|right-wing populist]] political parties and organizations fuel fear and hatred towards Islam and Muslims.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/story/poland-populist-government-far-right-extremism|title=Poland's populist government let far-right extremism explode into mainstream|first=Tim|last=Hume|date=9 May 2017|publisher=|via=news.vice.com}}</ref> Hate crimes such as arson and physical violence have occurred in Poland (despite having a Muslim population of only 0.1%, that is 30,000 out of 38 million).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/can-europe-make-it/kasia-narkowicz-konrad-pedziwiatr/why-are-polish-people-so-wrong-about-muslims-in|title=Why are Polish people so wrong about Muslims in their country?|date=13 January 2017|publisher=openDemocracy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.islamophobiaeurope.com/reports/2015/en/EIR_2015_POLAND.pdf|title=European Islamophobia Report|date=2015|publisher=SETA}}</ref> In 2016, police arrested a man who they say tried to burn down a [[mosque]] in [[Gdansk]].<ref name="Europol16">{{cite web|title=EUROPEAN UNION TERRORISM SITUATION AND TREND REPORT (TE-SAT) 2016|url=https://www.europol.europa.eu/activities-services/main-reports/european-union-terrorism-situation-and-trend-report-te-sat-2016|year=2016|publisher=[[Europol]]|page=41}}</ref> The man belonged to the neo-nazi group called [[Blood & Honour]].
=== Russia === [[The Savior (paramilitary organization)|The Savior]] was a [[neo-Nazi]] militant [[nationalist]] organization which claimed credit for the August [[2006 Moscow market bombing]], which killed 13. Media reports indicate that the market, located near [[Cherkizovsky]], was targeted due to its high volume of [[Central Asia]]n and [[Caucasus|Caucasian]] clientele.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/8CE01B4F-F6C4-4769-9CF0-1CE5C47ADDF0.htm|title=Russian court jails market bombers|date=15 May 2008|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref><ref>Marcel Van Herpen ''Putinism: The Slow Rise of a Radical Right Regime in Russia'' 2013 "On August, 21, 2006, members of The Savior, a neo-Nazi group led by Nikolai Korolev, a former FSB officer, bombed the Cherkizovsky market in Moscow, the largest market of Russia, frequented by many merchants from Central Asia."</ref> Four members of The Saviour were sentenced to life imprisonment, while four others received lesser prison terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russiatoday.ru/news/news/24782|title=Racist bombers sentenced to life for market blast|publisher=Russia Today}}</ref>
On 22 April 2017, A gunman 'with hatred for ethnic minorities' shot and killed two people in an attack in a Federal Security Service office in the Russian city of Khabarovsk. The gunman was also killed. The Russian Federal Security Service says the native 18-year-old perpetrator was a known member of a neo-nazi group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/murderous-attack-on-fsb-office-in-khabarovsk-was-by-a-neo-nazi-not-an-is-terrorist/|title=Murderous attack on FSB office in Khabarovsk 'was by a neo-Nazi - not an IS terrorist'|website=siberiantimes.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref>
=== Sweden === Both the [[2009–10 Malmö shootings]] and the [[Trollhättan school attack]] were conducted by right-wing terrorists along with a refugee centre bombing in 2017. A notable serial killer motivated by far-right motives is [[John Ausonius]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/donald-trump-terror-attack-claim-sweden-neo-nazis-refugee-centre-florida-rally-a7588516.html|title=Donald Trump is right, there was a recent attack in Sweden. By neo-Nazis on a refugee centre|date=19 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Far-rightists were also responsible for attacking an anti-racist demonstration [[December 2013 Stockholm riots|in Stockholm in December 2013]].
=== United Kingdom === In April 1999, David Copeland, a neo-Nazi, planted a [[1999 London nail bombings|series of nail bombs]] over 13 days. His attacks, which were aimed at London's [[Black people|black]], [[British Bangladeshi|Bangladeshi]] and [[Homosexual|gay]] communities, resulted in three dead and more than 100 injured.<ref name=Buncombe>Buncombe, Andrew; Judd, Terri; and Bennett, Jason. [https://web.archive.org/web/20091201133942/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/hatefilled-nailbomber-is-jailed-for-life-706785.html "'Hate-filled' nailbomber is jailed for life"], ''The Independent'', 30 June 2000.</ref> Copeland was a former member of two far right political groups, the [[British National Party]] (BNP) and the [[National Socialist Movement (United Kingdom)|National Socialist Movement]]. Copeland told police, "My aim was political. It was to cause a racial war in this country. There'd be a backlash from the ethnic minorities, then all the white people will go out and vote BNP."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/audio_video/programmes/panorama/transcripts/transcript_30_06_00.txt "The Nailbomber"], BBC Panorama, 30 June 2000.</ref>
In July 2007, Robert Cottage, a former BNP member, was convicted for possessing explosive chemicals in his home – described by police at the time of his arrest as the largest amount of chemical explosive of its type ever found in that country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2009/07/mehdi-hasan-muslim-terrorism-white-british|title=Know your enemy|publisher=}}</ref> In June 2008, Martyn Gilleard, a British Nazi sympathizer, was jailed after police found nail bombs, bullets, swords, axes and knives in his flat.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7471128.stm | work=BBC News | title=Man guilty over nail bombs plot | date=June 24, 2008}}</ref> Also in 2008, Nathan Worrell was found guilty of possession of material for terrorist purposes and racially aggravated harassment. He was described by anti-terror police as a "dangerous individual". The court heard that police found books and manuals containing "recipes" to make bombs and detonators using household items, such as weedkiller, at Worrell's flat.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/dec/13/uk-security-nazi-terrorist-jailed | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Racist who had bomb kit jailed for campaign against couple | date=December 13, 2008}}</ref> In July 2009, Neil Lewington was planning on waging a terror campaign using weapons made from tennis balls and weedkiller against those he classified as "non British".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8124449.stm | work=BBC News | title=Man 'on cusp' of bombing campaign | date=June 29, 2009}}</ref>
In 2012, the British Home Affairs Committee warned of the threat of far right terrorism in the UK, claiming it had heard "persuasive evidence" about the potential danger and cited the growth of similar threats across Europe.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16900108 | work=BBC News | title=Home Affairs Committee warns of far-right terror threat | date=February 6, 2012}}</ref>
Members of [[Combat 18]] (C18), a [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]] organisation based on the concept of "[[leaderless resistance]]", have been suspected in numerous deaths of immigrants, non-whites and other C18 members.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/panorama/1672100.stm | work=BBC News | title=Ex-Combat 18 man speaks out | date=25 November 2001}}</ref> Between 1998 and 2000, dozens of members were arrested.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/1999/03/07/narm07.html "MI5 swoops on Army 'neo-Nazis'"], ''Sunday Telegraph'', 7 March 1999</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/in_depth/programmes/2001/bnp_special/membership/organisers/adrian_marsden.stm BNP Under the skin: Profile of Adrian Marsden], ''BBC News''</ref> A group calling itself the [[Racial Volunteer Force]] split from C18 in 2002, retaining close links to its parent organization.<ref>[http://www.meta-religion.com/Extremism/White_extremism/Combat_18/combat_18.htm "Combat 18"] at www.metareligion.com</ref> Some journalists believed that the [[White Wolves]] were a C18 splinter group, alleging that the group had been set up by [[Del O'Connor]], the former second-in-command of C18 and member of [[Skrewdriver]] Security.<ref>Stuart Millar, [https://www.theguardian.com/bombs/Story/0,2763,204778,00.html "Anti-terror police seek White Wolf racist over bombs"]</ref> C18 attacks on immigrants continued through 2009.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/belfast-racists--threaten-to-cut-romanian-babys-throat-14341494.html "Belfast racists threaten to cut Romanian baby's throat"], ''Belfast Telegraph'', 17 June 2009</ref> Weapons, ammunition and explosives were seized by police in the UK and almost every country in which C18 was active.
In 2016, [[Jo Cox]], the [[Member of parliament|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for the [[Batley and Spen (UK Parliament constituency)|Batley and Spen]] constituency [[Murder of Jo Cox|was murdered]] by Thomas Mair, who was motivated by far-right political views and had connections to several far-right organisations in the UK, US, and South Africa.<ref>Ian Cobain and Matthew Taylor, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/nov/23/thomas-mair-found-guilty-of-jo-cox-murder Far-right terrorist Thomas Mair jailed for life for Jo Cox murder], ''Guardian'' (November 23, 2017).</ref>
On 16 December 2016 [[Home Secretary]] [[Amber Rudd]] designated the far-right, neo-Nazi [[National Action (UK)|National Action]] group as a terrorist organisation which criminalises membership or support for the organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/12/neo-nazi-group-national-action-banned-by-uk-home-secretary|title=Neo-Nazi group National Action banned by UK home secretary|first=Jessica|last=Elgot|date=12 December 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> On 12 June 2018, [[Jack Renshaw (far-right activist)|Jack Renshaw]], 23, a former spokesperson for [[National Action (UK)|National Action]], admitted in a guilty plea to buying a 48 cm (19 in) replica [[Ancient Rome|Roman]][[Gladius]] sword (often wrongly referred to in the media as a [[machete]]) to murder Rosie Cooper, the [[Member of parliament|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for the [[West Lancashire (UK Parliament constituency)|West Lancashire]] constituency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jun/12/man-pleads-guilty-to-plot-to-labour-mp-rosie-cooper|title=Alleged neo-Nazi admits plotting murder of MP Rosie Cooper|last=Khomami|first=Nadia|date=2018-06-12|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-04}}</ref>
In March 2018 [[Mark Rowley]], the outgoing head of UK counter-terror policing, revealed that four far-right terror plots had been foiled since the Westminster attack in March 2017.<ref>{{url="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/terror-attacks-uk-threat-far-right-national-action-isis-nazis-westminster-finsbury-park-a8229876.html|date=26 February 2|title=Four far-right UK terrorist plots foiled since Westminster attack, police reveal}}</ref>
==== Northern Ireland ==== British far-right activists supplied funds and weaponry to [[Ulster loyalism|Loyalist]] terrorist groups in [[Northern Ireland]] during [[the Troubles]].<ref name="Goodrick-Clarke2003">{{cite book|first=Nicholas |last=Goodrick-Clarke|title=Black Sun: Aryan Cults, Esoteric Nazism, and the Politics of Identity|url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=xaiaM77s6N4C|page=40}}|date=1 July 2003|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0-8147-3155-0|pp=40–41, 45}}</ref> Following the [[Good Friday Agreement]] some members of Loyalist groups orchestrated racist attacks in Northern Ireland,<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/uvf-behind-racist-attacks-in-south-and-east-belfast-loyalist-paramilitary-group-behind-attacks-says-psni-30153199.html "UVF 'behind racist attacks in south and east Belfast'"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'', 3 April 2014.</ref><ref name=chrisafis>Chrisafis, Angelique. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/jan/10/northernireland.race "Racist war of the loyalist street gangs"]. ''[[The Guardian]]'', 10 January 2004.</ref><ref name=bbcjan04>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/3390249.stm "Race hate on rise in NI"]. BBC News, 13 January 2004.</ref> including [[pipe bomb]] and gun attacks on the homes of immigrants.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-26495821 "Two arrested over racist pipe bomb attacks in Londonderry"]. BBC News, 10 March 2014.</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/3042246.stm "Loyalists hit out at racist attacks"]. BBC News, 3 July 2003.</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4602045.stm "Police probe after bomb attacks"]. BBC News, 2 June 2005.</ref><ref>[http://www.belfastdaily.co.uk/2013/05/25/mother-of-south-belfast-racist-attack-to-leave-home/ "Mother of South Belfast racist attack to leave home"]. Belfast Daily. 25 May 2013.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-27143857 "Gun attack: Family at home during 'hate crime' in west Belfast"]. BBC News, 24 April 2014.</ref> As a result, Northern Ireland has a higher proportion of racist attacks than other parts of the UK,<ref name=bbcjan04/><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/bitter-tide-of-violent-racial-hate-recalls-the-worst-of-the-troubles-26223356.html "Bitter tide of violent racial hate recalls the worst of the Troubles"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]'', 8 August 2004.</ref> and was branded the "race-hate capital of Europe".<ref>[http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/ulster-is-race-hate-capital-of-europe-264958.html "Ulster 'is race hate capital of Europe'"]. BreakingNews.ie. 26 June 2006.</ref>
== Oceania == === Australia === In August 2016 Phillip Galea was charged with several terrorist offences. Galea had conducted "surveillance" of "left-wing premises" and planned to carry out bombings. Explosive ingredients were found at his home. Galea had links with organisations such as [[Combat 18]] and the [[United Patriots Front]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/oct/31/victorian-extremist-phillip-galea-planned-to-bomb-leftwing-premises-police-say|title=Victorian extremist Phillip Galea planned to bomb leftwing premises, police say|first=Australian Associated|last=Press|date=31 October 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> In 2017 the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' reported on the conviction of neo-Nazi Michael James Holt, 26 who had threatened to carry out a mass shooting attack and considered [[Westfield Tuggerah]] as a target. He had manufactured home-made guns, knuckle dusters and slingshots in his grandfather's garage. Raids on his mother's home and a hotel room discovered more weapons including several firearms, slingshots and knuckle dusters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/white-supremacist-threatened-to-shoot-up-sydney-shopping-centre-20170120-gtvod0.html|title=White supremacist threatened to shoot up Central Coast shopping centre|first=Rachel|last=Olding|date=28 January 2017|publisher=|via=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>

revision.text: {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2012}} {{multiple issues|{{example farm|date=January 2017}} {{original research|date=April 2008}}}} A '''satiric misspelling''' is an intentional misspelling of a word, phrase or name for a [[rhetoric]]al purpose. This is often done by replacing a letter with another letter (for example, ''[[k]]'' replacing ''[[c]]''), or symbol (for example, ''[[$]]'' replacing ''[[s]]'', ''[[@]]'' replacing ''[[a]]'', or ''[[¢]]'' replacing ''c''). Satiric misspelling is found particularly in [[Internet slang|informal writing on the Internet]], but can also be found in some serious political writing that opposes the [[status quo]]. == ''K'' replacing ''c'' == Replacing the letter ''c'' with ''k'' in the first letter of a word came into use by the [[Ku Klux Klan]] during its early years in the mid-to-late 19th century. The concept is continued today within the group. [[File:Barc okupa.jpg|thumb|Barcelona squat and anarchist centre, labelled "OKUPA Y RESISTE"]] In the 1960s and early 1970s in the [[United States]], [[left-wing politics|leftists]], particularly the [[Yippies]], sometimes used ''[[Amerika (disambiguation)|Amerika]]'' rather than ''America'' in referring to the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.schwarzreport.org/Newsletters/1969/november15,69.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123223245/http://www.schwarzreport.org/Newsletters/1969/november15%2C69.htm |title=CACC NEWSLETTER |archivedate=January 23, 2008 |work=schwarzreport.org |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://hippy.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=81|title=A Call to Arms (1969?) - Hippy Land, Home of the Hippies|work=hippy.com}}{{cite web|url=http://riseup.net/sds/graphics.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050726012713/http://riseup.net/sds/graphics.htm |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|archivedate=July 26, 2005 |work=riseup.net}}http://www2.lib.virginia.edu/exhibits/sixties/radical.html{{cite web|url=http://www1.american.edu/bgriff/H207web/sixties/rubinchildofAmerika.htm|title=Jerry Rubin: Self-Portrait of a Child of "Amerika," 1970|work=american.edu}} It is still used as a political statement today.{{cite web|url=http://www.jasonalexandercruz.com/|title=Nachrichten aus der Musik- und Entertainmentbranche - Jasonalexandercruz.com|work=jasonalexandercruz.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/guinnessgurl/sets/148438/|title=political|work=Flickr}} It is likely that this was originally an allusion to the [[German language|German]] spelling of the word, and intended to be suggestive of [[Nazism]], a hypothesis that the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' supports. In broader usage, the replacement of the letter ''c'' with ''k'' denotes general political skepticism about the topic at hand and is intended to discredit or debase the term in which the replacement occurs.{{cite web|title=LeSaint's Sloth Cave|url=http://www.le-saint.com/wear.html|accessdate=29 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929121925/http://www.le-saint.com/wear.html |archivedate=September 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} A similar usage in [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Catalan Language|Catalan]] and [[Portuguese Language|Portuguese]]{{Citation needed|date=February 2010}} is to write ''okupa'' rather than ''ocupa'' (often on a building or area occupied by [[squatter]]s,{{cite web|url=http://comunidades.calle22.com/comunidades/397/com397con2.asp |title=comunidades.calle22.com - TODOS SOMOS OKUPAS |accessdate=2004-10-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611121504/http://comunidades.calle22.com/comunidades/397/com397con2.asp |archivedate=June 11, 2008 |df= }} referring to the name adopted by ''okupación'' activist groups), which is particularly remarkable because the letter "k" is not part of the Spanish, Portuguese or Italian alphabets. It stems from a combination of English borrow words with k in them to those languages, and [[Anarchism in Spain|Spanish anarchist]] and [[Punk rock|punk]] movements which used "k" to signal rebellion.{{cite web|last=Rodríguez González|first=Félix|year=2006|title=Medios de comunicación y contracultura juvenil|work=Círculo|volume=25:5–30|url=http://www.ucm.es/info/circulo/no25/rodriguez.pdf|format=PDF}} Replacing "c" with "k" was at the centre of a [[Monty Python]] joke from the Travel Agent sketch. [[Eric Idle]] has an affliction that makes him pronounce the letter C as a B, as in "bolour" instead of "colour." [[Michael Palin]] asks him if he can say the letter K? Idle replies that he can, and Palin suggests that he spell words with a K instead of C. Idle replies, "what, spell bolour with a K? Kolour. Oh! I never thought of that before! What a silly [[Cunt#Comedy|bunt]]!"{{cite web|title=Transcript|url=http://web.mit.edu/humor/Special/Monty.Python/travel.agency|work=Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Index of Humor|accessdate=29 May 2015}} The video game franchise [[Mortal Kombat]] is another example of this trend. ===''KKK'' replacing ''c'' or ''k''=== A common satiric usage of the letters ''KKK'' is the spelling of ''America'' as ''Amerikkka'', alluding to the [[Ku Klux Klan]], drawing to a perceived notion of an underlying or inherent [[Racism in the United States|racism]] in American society. The earliest known usage of ''Amerikkka'' recorded in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' is in 1970, in a journal called ''Black World''. Presumably, this was an extrapolation from the then already widespread ''Amerika''.{{Clarify|date=December 2014}}{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} The spelling ''Amerikkka'' came into greater use after the 1990 release of the [[gangsta rap]] album ''[[AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted]]'' by [[Ice Cube]], also used by rapper [[Spice 1]] for his album ''[[AmeriKKKa's Nightmare]]'' and by [[shock rock]] band [[Undercover Slut]] for their album ''Amerikkka Macht Frei''.{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} The letters ''KKK'' have been inserted into several other words and names, to indicate similar perceived racism, oppression or corruption. Examples include: * ''Republikkkan'' ([[Republican Party (United States)|U.S. Republican Party]]){{cite web|url=http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |title=The Blackstripe - Stolen 2000 Election |accessdate=2004-10-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060225154916/http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |archivedate=February 25, 2006 |df= }} * ''Demokkkrat'' ([[Democratic Party (United States)|U.S. Democratic Party]]){{cite web|url=http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |title=The Blackstripe - Stolen 2000 Election |accessdate=2004-10-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060225154916/http://www.blackstripe.com/archives/views/abanks/shrub.html |archivedate=February 25, 2006 |df= }} * ''KKKapitalism'' ([[capitalism]]){{cite web|url=http://home4.inet.tele.dk/lepan/lene/indiana/mscritical.htm |title=From Critical Reflections to Forward Progression |accessdate=2005-11-04 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104162056/http://home4.inet.tele.dk/lepan/lene/indiana/mscritical.htm |archivedate=November 4, 2005 |df=mdy }} * ''KKKommunism'' ([[communism]]){{cite web|url=http://www.therightperspective.org/2008/08/22/kommunism-is-aprtheid/|title=Kommunism is Apartheid!|author=frankvonqueens|date=2008-08-22|accessdate=2012-11-28|work=The Right Perspective|publisher=[[Peter Goodman]]}} * ''David DuKKKe'' ([[David Duke]]), former [[Grand Wizard]] of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], candidate for [[United States Senate]], candidate for [[Governor of Louisiana]], and now [[YouTube]] and web [[antisemitic conspiracy theory|antisemitic conspiracy theorist]]{{cite book|last1=Barkun|first1=Michael|title=Religion and the Racist Right: The Origins of the Christian Identity Movement|date=1997|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=9780807846384|page=315|edition=illustrated, revised|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bdGSbDaCQVsC&pg=PA315|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ==Currency signs== The [[US dollar|dollar]] sign ($) can be inserted in the place of the letter ''S'', the [[euro]] sign (€) in place of ''[[e]]'', the [[Japanese yen|yen]] (¥) sign in place of ''[[Y]]'', the [[South Korean won|won]] (₩) sign in place of ''[[W]]'', or the [[pound sterling|pound]] (£) sign in place of ''[[L]],'' or the [[Indian rupee|rupee]] sign (₹) in place of ''R'' to indicate [[plutocracy]], [[greed (emotion)|greed]], [[political corruption|corruption]], or the perceived immoral, unethical, or pathological accumulation of [[money]]. For example: * ''App£e'' (for [[Apple Inc.]]);{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} see also [[Criticism of Apple Inc.]]. * ''Autism $peaks'' (for [[Autism Speaks]]),{{cite web|last1=Cincotta |first1=Frank |last2=Binns |first2=Rebecca |title=Autism $peaks U are Clueless |url=http://arisespringfield.org/autism-peaks-u-are-clueless/ |work=Arise for Social Justice |accessdate=29 May 2015 |date=8 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529174249/http://arisespringfield.org/autism-peaks-u-are-clueless/ |archivedate=May 29, 2015 }} often used on blogging sites such as [[Tumblr]].{{cite web|title=#autism $peaks on Tumblr|url=https://www.tumblr.com/tagged/autism-$peaks|publisher=Tumblr|accessdate=29 May 2015}} * ''Bu$h'' (for [[George W. Bush]], [[George Herbert Walker Bush]], or any member of the [[Bush family]]){{cite web|url=https://www.ledevoir.com/non-classe/41033/stoppez-bu-h |title=«Stoppez Bu$h |publisher=Le Devoir |date=}}{{cite web|url=http://archive.democrats.com/view.cfm?id=8158 |title=Caught in the Crossfire: What Will Bu$h Do About Corporate Corruption? |publisher=Archive.democrats.com |date=June 28, 2002 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2003/11/281262.html |title=UK Indymedia - Stop Bu$h - National Demonstration - Thursday 20th |publisher=Indymedia.org.uk |date=November 20, 2003 }} * Congre$$ (for [[United States Congress]]){{citation needed|date=August 2014}}. * ''Co$'' or ''$cientology'' (for the [[Church of Scientology]]){{cite web|url=http://www.xenu.org/cartoon/ |title=The $cientology Cartoon Page |accessdate=2005-02-24 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302124138/http://www.xenu.org/cartoon/ |archivedate=March 2, 2007 |df= }} * ''Di$ney'' and ''Di$neyland''{{cite web|url=http://www.bakersfield.com/news/opinion/2014/12/17/joe-mathews-di-neyland-ought-to-give-kids-a-break.html|title=JOE MATHEWS: Di$neyland ought to give kids a break|author=By|work=The Bakersfield Californian}} See [[Criticism of The Walt Disney Company]] and [[Disneyland#Tickets]] * ''E$$o'' (for [[Esso]]): Used by the UK-based [[Stop Esso campaign]] encouraging people to [[boycott]] Esso, in protest against Esso's opposition to the [[Kyoto Protocol]].{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/climate/interview-with-a-stop-esso-activist|title=Interview with a Stop Esso activist|work=[[Greenpeace]]|date=November 29, 2001|accessdate=December 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108231651/http://www.greenpeace.org.uk/climate/interview-with-a-stop-esso-activist|archivedate=January 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}} * ''Hill$ong'' (for [[Hillsong Church]]): Used by people against the Hillsong Church to state that they exist only to take offerings to be used for workers' luxury rather than Christian-like charitable uses.{{cite web|url=http://www.cwm.org.au/3/24-52/271-9|title=Christian Witness Ministries - Why I left Hill$ong Brisbane Campus|author=Lance Goodall|work=cwm.org.au}}{{better source|reason=The source uses the phrase in question but doesn't comment on it or explain the joke. The material it is cited for is original research.|date=July 2015}} * "[[Green Chri$tma$]]", a song by [[Stan Freberg]], satirizing [[Commercialization of Christmas]] * ''I$rael'', among those who perceive [[Israel]] as overtly [[Israel-United States relations|dependant on the United States]],{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} and sometimes also as a manifestation of the anti-Semitic belief that Jews are [[Antisemitic canard#Accusations of usury and profiteering|overtly obsessed]] with money and/or [[Antisemitic canard#Accusations of controlling the world financial system|control the financial markets]].{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} * [[Kesha|Ke$ha]]: Pop music artist. She adopted the dollar sign in her name while struggling to get by as an ironic gesture.{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/K/Kesha/2010/01/19/12529526-qmi.html |title=View Single Post - Pop sensation Ke$ha gutsy, fearless |publisher=jam.canoe.ca |date=January 19, 2010 }} * ''kla$$'' (for [[class conflict|class]]): Used to draw attention to the belief that American citizens are widely and unfairly ranked solely on terms of their material wealth * ''[[Mase|Ma$e]]'': Rapper who formerly used to stylize his stage name with a dollar sign in place of an S. * ''McDonald'$'' * ''Micro$oft'', ''M$'', ''M$FT'' (for [[Microsoft]]), as well as ''Micro$oft Windoze'' for [[Microsoft Windows]];{{cite web|url=http://www.madore.org/~david/computers/antims.html |title=A plea against Micro$oft |publisher=madore.org |author=David Madore |date= }} see also [[Criticism of Microsoft]] * ''Orac£e'' (for [[Oracle Corporation]]){{citation needed|date=August 2014}} * ''Ro£€x or'' ₹''o£€x'' (for [[Rolex]]){{citation needed|date=August 2014}} * ''Ru$$ia'' (for [[Russia]]){{cite web|url=http://www.zaimka.ru/today/olekh6.shtml |title=Olekh G. На пороге будущего… "Сибирская Заимка" —история Сибири в научных публикациях |publisher=Zaimka.ru |date= }} * ''$ky'' (for [[Sky plc]]), used by those who perceive the British pay-TV broadcaster as an overt Americanising force. * ''$ocialism'' or ''$ociali$m'' (for [[Socialism]]): Critics{{who|date=August 2014}} have pointed out that the idea of socialism has been exploited for profit, by politicians, corporations and artists, in particular as a criticism of [[Michael Moore]].[http://www.regainingsteam.com/blog/crony55.html ]{{dead link|date=August 2014}}[http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/fighting_words/20010/09/michael_a_success_story.html ]{{dead link|date=August 2012}} * ''$ony'' (for [[Sony]]){{citation needed|date=May 2015}} * ''Uncle $am'' (for [[Uncle Sam]]){{cite web|url=http://www.countryjoe.com/fixins.htm |title=Country Joe McDonald, All the Fixin's |publisher=Countryjoe.com |date= }} * ''United $tates'', ''United $tate$'', ''U$'', ''U$A'' (for the [[United States]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.infoshop.org/gulag/stories.php?story=03%2F02%2F14%2F9738882 |title=American Gulag - Dismantle the Prison-Industrial Complex |accessdate=2017-05-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041223062105/http://www.infoshop.org/gulag/stories.php?story=03%2F02%2F14%2F9738882 |archivedate=December 23, 2004 |df= }} * ''₩a$hington'' (for [[Washington, D.C.]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.etext.org/Politics/MIM/mn/html/mn261.html |title=MIM Notes - Bush signs $190 billion farm bill opposing 'free trade' |accessdate=2004-10-08 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123081354/http://www.etext.org/Politics/MIM/mn/html/mn261.html |archivedate=January 23, 2008 |df= }} * ''₩indo₩$'' (for [[Microsoft Windows]]){{cite web|url=http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/showpost.php?p=4108262 |title=View Single Post - The All New Linux vs Windows MegaSuperThread |publisher=LinuxQuestions.org |date=September 24, 2010 }} == @ replacing A, at or O== Since at least 1980, people have used the "at sign" ("[[@]]") as a representation of the [[Anarchy a|circled letter A]]. This has been extended to substituting it for the letter "A" as in the [[Crass]] [[fanzine]] ''Toxic Gr@fity''.{{cite web|url=http://www.southern.com/southern/label/CRC/1980.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206073619/http://www.southern.com/southern/label/CRC/1980.html|archivedate=December 6, 2010|deadurl=yes|title=Crass Discography}} In Spanish, it became informally common (but not accepted by the [[Real Academia Espanola|RAE]], due to @ being a symbol and not a letter) to use @ in place of "o/a" to denote both genders. For example, "señorit@" can be used to mean "señorita and/or señorito" instead of using "señorita/o." ==Word-in-word== Occasionally a word written in its orthodox spelling is altered with internal capital letters, hyphens, italics, or other devices so as to highlight a fortuitous pun. Some examples: * After the controversial [[U.S. presidential election, 2000|2000 U.S. Presidential elections]], the alleged improprieties of the election prompted the use of such titles as "pResident" and "(p)resident"{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20010326&s=contest |archive-url=https://archive.is/20060530225708/http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20010326&s=contest |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 30, 2006 |title=Name the President! |date=March 18, 2006 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gainesvillehumanists.org/alerts.htm |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 14, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041013030443/http://www.gainesvillehumanists.org/alerts.htm |archivedate=October 13, 2004 |df= }} for [[George W. Bush]]. The same effects were also used for [[Bill Clinton]] during and after Clinton's impeachment hearings. These devices were intended to suggest that the president was merely the ''resident'' of the [[White House]] rather than the legitimate leader. * Similarly, the controversial [[United States]] law, the ''[[USA PATRIOT Act]]'', is sometimes called the "patRiot Act", "(pat)Riot Act", "PAT Riot Act", "PAT RIOT Act", or "You Sap At Riot Act"{{cite web|url=http://www.stallman.org/pat-riot-act.html |title=PAT RIOT Act - Richard Stallman |publisher=Stallman.org |date= }}{{cite web|url=http://yro.slashdot.org/comments.pl?sid=115660&cid=9794643 |title=Slashdot Comments | British Columbia Acts Against Patriot Act |publisher=Yro.slashdot.org |date=July 25, 2004 }} by its opponents. * Feminist theologian [[Mary Daly]] has used a [[slash (punctuation)|slash]] to make a point about [[patriarchy]]: "gyn/ecology", "stag/nation", "the/rapist".[http://www.salon.com/it/feature/1999/03/17feature.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050128070855/http://www.salon.com/it/feature/1999/03/17feature.html |date=January 28, 2005 }} * In French, where ''con'' is an insulting word meaning "moron", the word ''conservateur'' (conservative) has been written "con-servateur",{{cite web|url=http://membres.lycos.fr/prince2/Elections/J30.HTM |title=Elections Québec '98 |date=June 11, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611134857/http://membres.lycos.fr/prince2/Elections/J30.HTM |archivedate=June 11, 2008 }} "con… servateur",{{cite web|url=http://www.chantiers.org/cri.htm |title=cri |publisher=Chantiers.org |date= }} or "con(servateur)".{{cite web|url=http://www.france-mail-forum.de/fmf31/pol/31ruscio.htm |title=France-Mail-Forum Nr. 31: Politique et histoire |date=June 11, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080611123723/http://www.france-mail-forum.de/fmf31/pol/31ruscio.htm |archivedate=June 11, 2008 }} The American English term ''neo-con'', an abbreviation of ''[[Neoconservatism|neo-conservative]]'', becomes a convenient pun when used in French.{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cgi-bin/ACHATS/acheter.cgi?offre=ARCHIVES&type_item=ART_ARCH_30J&objet_id=893321 |title=Les deux vies de " Wolfie ", le " néo-con " au " coeur qui saigne |publisher=LeMonde.fr |date= }} In English, the first syllable of ''con''servative can be emphasized to suggest a [[Confidence trick|con artist]].{{cite web|author=Jane Kleeb |url=http://www.boldnebraska.org/con-servative-bait-and-switch |title="Con"servative Bait and Switch |publisher=Boldnebraska.org |date=July 2, 2010 |accessdate=2012-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402114344/http://www.boldnebraska.org/con-servative-bait-and-switch |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df=mdy }} * The British political satire magazine ''[[Private Eye]]'' has a long-standing theme of insulting the law firm [[Carter-Ruck]] by replacing the R with an F to read Carter-Fuck. The law firm once requested that Private Eye cease spelling its name like that; the magazine then started spelling it "Farter-Fuck".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1450022/Peter-Carter-Ruck.html|title=Peter Carter-Ruck|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|date=22 December 2003|accessdate=27 January 2015}} Likewise, ''Private Eye'' often refers to ''[[The Guardian]]'' as ''[[The Grauniad]]'',{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2000/dec/16/society|title=Surely shome mishtake?|work=The Guardian|date=16 December 2000| location=London|last=Sherrin|first=Ned|authorlink=Ned Sherrin}} due to the newspaper's early reputation for [[typographical errors]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_oO5fWi6dikC&pg=PA26 |pages=26–27 |title=Porcupine, Picayune, & Post: how newspapers get their names |first=Jim|last=Bernhard|publisher=University of Missouri Press|year=2007|isbn=0-8262-1748-6|accessdate=11 August 2013}} * Netizens often called [[Bong Revilla|Sen. Ramon "Bong" Revilla Jr.]] as "''MandaramBONG''" (Filipino word for [[plunder]]er) to highlight allegations that he pocketed pork barrel funds through the use of fake non-government organizations.{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/01/20/14/mandarambong-netizens-twit-revilla-speech |title='MandaramBong': Netizens twit Revilla speech |work=ABS-CBN News |date=2014-01-20}} == Other significant respellings == {{See also|Misnomer}} Along the same lines, intentional misspellings can be used to promote a specific negative attribute, real or perceived, of a product or service. This is especially effective if the misspelling is done by replacing part of the word with another that has identical phonetic qualities. Some [[toponyms|place names]] are also spelled differently in order to emphasize some political view. For instance, ''Brasil'' (the Portuguese spelling of "Brazil"), is sometimes misconstrued as a typo for ''Brazil'' in English texts.{{cite web |url=http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definition/brasil |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-09-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927190200/http://www.websters-online-dictionary.org/definition/brasil |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Alternatively, the English spelling ''Brazil'' is used in Portuguese pieces of text as a way to denote [[anti-Americanism]] or [[Anti-globalization|anti-globalization sentiment]]. Journalists may make a politicized editorial decision by choosing to differentially retain (or even create) misspellings, mispronunciations, ungrammaticisms, dialect variants, or interjections. ===Backronyms=== {{Main|Backronym}} Plays on [[acronym]]s and [[initialism]]s are also common, when the full name is spelled out but one of the component words is replaced by another. For example, [[Richard Stallman]] and other [[Free Software Foundation]] executives often refer to [[digital rights management]] as "digital '''restrictions''' management",[[Digital rights management#Opposition to DRM]] a reference to the tendency for DRM to stifle the end user's ability to reshare music or write CDs more than a certain number of times. Likewise, the [[National Security Agency]] is often referred to as the "National '''Surveillance''' Agency"{{cite web|url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/2615652243001/national-surveillance-agency-audit-reveals-nsa-violations|title=National 'Surveillance' Agency? Audit reveals NSA violations|work=Fox News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.idigitaltimes.com/articles/18295/20130614/nsa-prism-apple-google-microsoft-glass-xbox.htm |title=National Surveillance Agency: Looking At Google Glass, Xbox One Through The NSA's Prism [OPINION] |date=June 14, 2013 |work=iDigitalTimes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928032348/http://www.idigitaltimes.com/articles/18295/20130614/nsa-prism-apple-google-microsoft-glass-xbox.htm |archivedate=September 28, 2013 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://n4g.com/news/1282615/national-surveillance-agency-looking-at-google-glass-xbox-one-through-the-nsas-prism|title=National Surveillance Agency: Looking At Google Glass, Xbox One Through The NSA's Prism|work=n4g.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=40803 |title=National Surveillance Agency program is still ongoing |author=Catholic Online |work=catholic.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225144748/http://www.catholic.org/politics/story.php?id=40803 |archivedate=December 25, 2013 |df=mdy }} and sometimes "[[Nazism|National Socialist]] Agency"http://quartermoonsaloon.com/forum/archive/index.php/t-21247.htmlhttp://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/national_socialist_agency_national_security_agency_or_nsa_nickname by opponents of its [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] program, who view it as dystopian encroachment on personal privacy. == See also == * [[Eye dialect]] * [[Herstory]] * [[Leet]] * [[Play on words]] * [[Pun]] * [[Sensational spelling]] * [[Womyn]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040925080243/http://home4.inet.tele.dk/lepan/lene/indiana/jun00.htm#Mangwiro On de spelling and use of various words] by Mangwiro A.
